name: SpaceX Starship Orbital Test Flight 3
details: Third full-stack Starship orbital flight test. Includes reentry testing and booster landing.

name: Artemis II
details: First crewed Artemis mission. Will orbit the Moon without landing.

name: Tianwen-1
details: China’s first independent Mars mission. Includes orbiter, lander, and rover (Zhurong).

name: Sputnik 1
details: First artificial Earth satellite; transmitted radio pulses for 22 days before atmospheric reentry on 4 Jan 1958.

name: Sputnik 2
details: Second spacecraft in the Sputnik program, and the first to carry a living being into orbit—Laika the dog. Weighing around 508 kg, Sputnik 2 carried scientific instruments for telemetry, temperature control, and photometric studies. Though Laika died from overheating hours after launch, the mission returned valuable data on life support systems in space. The spacecraft remained in orbit for over five months, reentering Earth’s atmosphere on 14 April 1958.

name: Explorer 1
details: First U.S. satellite, carrying a cosmic ray detector that led to the discovery of the Van Allen radiation belts. It orbited Earth every ~114 minutes and transmitted data until May 23, 1958; it reentered March 31, 1970.

name: Vanguard 1
details: Fourth Earth satellite and first solar‑powered satellite. Used for geodetic measurements and studying upper‑atmospheric density. Although communications ceased in 1964, it remains the oldest man‑made object still in orbit.

name: Luna 1
details: First spacecraft to reach escape velocity and orbit the Sun. Released a sodium gas cloud for tracking and provided first in‑space measurements of solar wind and outer radiation belts.

name: Pioneer 4
details: Pioneer 4 was the first American spacecraft to escape Earth's gravity and enter solar orbit. It conducted a flyby of the Moon at a distance of about 60,000 km, transmitting radiation data back to Earth.

name: Vanguard 2
details: The first weather satellite, designed to measure cloud cover distribution. While the satellite reached orbit, its spin axis was poorly aligned, reducing the effectiveness of the onboard instruments.

name: Explorer 6
details: Explorer 6 returned the first satellite photos of Earth from orbit and measured radiation, magnetic fields, and micrometeoroids in space. It was an important step in early Earth science missions.

name: Luna 2
details: Luna 2 became the first human-made object to impact the Moon. It confirmed that the Moon had no magnetic field and helped demonstrate Soviet launch capabilities during the space race.

name: Luna 3
details: Luna 3 was the first spacecraft to photograph the far side of the Moon, revealing a dramatically different terrain than the near side. These photos were processed and transmitted back to Earth.

name: Pioneer 5
details: Pioneer 5 was designed to study interplanetary magnetic fields between Earth and Venus. It operated successfully for about 106 days, sending back data on solar flares and cosmic radiation.

name: Sputnik 5
details: Sputnik 5 carried two dogs, Belka and Strelka, along with plants, insects, and mice. It was the first spaceflight to safely return living animals from orbit, paving the way for human spaceflight.

name: Pioneer P-30
details: Pioneer P-30 was intended to enter lunar orbit and study radiation and micrometeorites. However, a third stage failure prevented the spacecraft from leaving Earth orbit. It marked another step in early lunar mission attempts.

name: Mercury-Redstone 2 (MR-2)
details: MR-2 carried Ham the chimpanzee on a suborbital test flight, validating life support systems and capsule controls ahead of the first American human spaceflight. Ham performed tasks during flight and returned safely.

name: Venera 1
details: Venera 1 was the first spacecraft aimed at another planet, Venus. Although contact was lost en route, it was a major milestone in deep space exploration and paved the way for future Venera missions.

name: Vostok 1
details: Vostok 1 carried Yuri Gagarin, making him the first human to journey into outer space and orbit the Earth. This historic mission lasted 108 minutes and marked the beginning of human spaceflight.

name: Freedom 7
details: Freedom 7 carried Alan Shepard, the first American in space, on a 15-minute suborbital flight. The mission demonstrated NASA's ability to send a human safely into space and recover them.

name: Vostok 2
details: Vostok 2 carried cosmonaut Gherman Titov into orbit for over 25 hours, marking the first time a human spent more than a day in space. The mission helped assess the effects of prolonged weightlessness.

name: OSO-1
details: OSO-1 was the first in a series of Orbiting Solar Observatories. It studied solar emissions, including ultraviolet and X-rays, and helped build foundational knowledge of solar activity.

name: Ranger 1
details: Ranger 1 was intended to test spacecraft systems and study cosmic rays and radiation. It failed to achieve its planned orbit due to a launch malfunction and reentered Earth's atmosphere after two days.

name: Ranger 2
details: Ranger 2 was another test of systems and instruments for future lunar missions. Like its predecessor, it failed to leave Earth orbit due to a malfunction and decayed after two days.

name: Ranger 3
details: Ranger 3 was intended to impact the Moon and transmit images on descent. Due to a trajectory error, it missed the Moon by over 36,000 km and entered heliocentric orbit instead.

name: Ranger 4
details: Ranger 4 was the first U.S. spacecraft to reach the Moon, but it failed to return data due to an onboard computer failure. It did impact the lunar surface as intended.

name: Ranger 5
details: Ranger 5 was designed to impact the Moon and send back scientific data, including gamma-ray and x-ray measurements. Due to a power failure, the spacecraft ceased operations prematurely and missed the Moon, entering solar orbit instead.

name: Vostok 3
details: Vostok 3 carried cosmonaut Andrian Nikolayev into orbit for nearly 4 days. The mission demonstrated human endurance in space and marked the first time two crewed spacecraft were in orbit simultaneously.

name: Luna 4
details: Luna 4 was the first Soviet attempt at a soft landing on the Moon. Due to a guidance system failure, it missed the Moon by about 8,336 km and entered heliocentric orbit.

name: Cosmos 21
details: Believed to be an attempted lunar orbiter, Cosmos 21 failed to leave Earth orbit due to a malfunction in the upper stage. It reentered Earth's atmosphere shortly after launch.

name: Vostok 4
details: Launched a day after Vostok 3, Vostok 4 carried cosmonaut Pavel Popovich. The mission achieved the first dual flight of two manned spacecraft in close proximity, setting the stage for future rendezvous operations.

name: Ranger 8
details: Ranger 8 transmitted over 7,000 high-resolution photographs of the Moon before impacting the lunar surface in Mare Tranquillitatis. Its images helped select the Apollo 11 landing site.

name: Ranger 9
details: Ranger 9 was the final Ranger mission, transmitting more than 5,800 images of the Moon. Its impact was broadcast live on television, demonstrating the Moon's surface in real time.

name: Lincoln Calibration Sphere 1
details: LCS-1 was a passive satellite used as a radar calibration target for missile tracking systems. It helped refine satellite tracking and space object detection technologies.

name: Ferdinand 1
details: First launch from Norway's Andøya site, carrying two instruments to study the polar ionosphere and auroral particles up to ~102 km altitude.

name: Mars 1
details: Mars 1 was the first Soviet probe sent toward Mars to study interplanetary space and attempt a flyby. It transmitted data on solar wind and micrometeorites, but contact was lost en route in March 1963.

name: Mariner 2
details: Mariner 2 was the first successful interplanetary mission, performing a flyby of Venus. It provided the first close-up measurements of another planet’s atmosphere and confirmed Venus's extremely high surface temperatures.

name: Vostok 6
details: Vostok 6 carried Valentina Tereshkova, the first woman in space. The mission lasted nearly 3 days and conducted observations alongside Vostok 5, which was in orbit at the same time.

name: X-15 Flight 90
details: Flown by pilot Joseph A. Walker, X-15 Flight 90 reached an altitude of 106 km (66 miles), qualifying as a spaceflight by U.S. standards. It was one of the early manned missions beyond the Kármán line.

name: Voskhod 1
details: Voskhod 1 was the first spaceflight to carry a multi-person crew. It flew without spacesuits to accommodate all three cosmonauts, and marked a major milestone in the space race by beating the U.S. Gemini program to multi-crew flight.

name: Voskhod 2
details: Voskhod 2 is famous for carrying out the first spacewalk (EVA) by cosmonaut Alexei Leonov. The mission demonstrated extravehicular capabilities but faced challenges during reentry due to spacecraft control issues.

name: Gemini 3
details: Gemini 3 was the first crewed Gemini flight, piloted by Gus Grissom and John Young. It tested the spacecraft’s maneuverability and introduced orbital adjustments for the first time in a U.S. mission.

name: Mariner 4
details: Mariner 4 was the first spacecraft to successfully fly by Mars and send back close-up images of another planet. It revolutionized understanding of the Martian surface and atmosphere.

name: Diamant A / A-1 (Astérix)
details: First French orbital rocket and satellite launch; placed the A‑1 (Astérix) satellite into orbit, making France the third country to launch its own satellite. The mission tested the three‑stage rocket and marked France’s entry into independent space capability.

name: Gemini 6A
details: Flown by Wally Schirra and Tom Stafford, Gemini 6A performed the first crewed rendezvous in orbit, approaching within 30 cm of Gemini 7 during a ~1-day mission.

name: Gemini 7
details: Crewed by Frank Borman and Jim Lovell, Gemini 7 spent 14 days in orbit—setting a duration record and serving as the target for Gemini 6A during the first rendezvous.

name: Luna 9
details: First spacecraft to perform a soft landing on the Moon and transmit panoramic images of the lunar surface. Landed in Oceanus Procellarum on 3 February 1966 and continued transmitting data and pictures for several days.

name: Venera 3
details: First human-made object to reach the surface of another planet. Launched 16 November 1965; contact was lost en route, but the probe still impacted Venus on 1 March 1966, marking a major milestone in planetary exploration.

name: Gemini‑Agena Target Vehicle
details: Uncrewed Agena‑D upper stage outfitted as a docking target for Gemini 8. Launched about 6 hours before the crewed Gemini to practice orbital rendezvous and docking—the first-ever docking of two spacecraft in orbit.

name: Luna 10
details: First spacecraft to orbit the Moon, entering lunar orbit on April 3, 1966, and even broadcasting the ‘Internationale’ radio signal. It carried instruments for gamma‑ray, plasma, micrometeoroid, and magnetic field measurements.

name: Lunar Orbiter 1
details: First American spacecraft to orbit the Moon, providing crucial photographs of landing sites for Apollo and Surveyor missions, as well as the first images of Earth from lunar orbit.

name: Cosmos 186 / Cosmos 188
details: Paired Soviet unmanned Soyuz spacecraft that completed the first fully automated docking in orbit on Oct 30, 1967. Cosmos 186 launched on Oct 27 (active), followed by Cosmos 188 on Oct 30 (passive). They docked ~62 min later, stayed linked for ~3½ hrs, and splashed down separately.

name: Surveyor 6
details: First spacecraft to lift off from the Moon after a soft landing; returned nearly 30,000 images and conducted soil analysis before ending operations in December 1967.

name: Zond 1
details: Zond 1 was intended to be a Venus flyby mission. Shortly after launch, the spacecraft suffered a gradual depressurization and eventually lost communication before reaching Venus.

name: Zond 5
details: First spacecraft to circle the Moon and return living specimens (tortoises, insects, plants). Conducted scientific observations and safely re‑entered, splashing down in the Indian Ocean on Sep 21, 1968.

name: Explorer 33
details: Explorer 33 was intended to go into lunar orbit, but an overburn by the launch vehicle placed it into a highly elliptical Earth orbit instead. It still provided useful space environment data.

name: Lunar Orbiter 4
details: Lunar Orbiter 4 was designed to provide broad coverage of the lunar surface, including the far side. It returned over 400 high-quality photographs, helping prepare for Apollo missions.

name: Venera 4
details: Venera 4 became the first spacecraft to return direct atmospheric data from another planet. It entered Venus’ atmosphere and transmitted temperature, pressure, and composition readings before contact was lost.

name: Mariner 5
details: Originally a backup for Mariner 4, Mariner 5 was repurposed for a Venus flyby. It collected vital atmospheric and surface pressure data, complementing Venera 4’s findings.

name: Surveyor 4
details: Surveyor 4 was intended to land in the Moon’s Sinus Medii region. Communication was lost just before touchdown, and the mission was considered a failure.

name: Explorer 35
details: Explorer 35 entered lunar orbit to study the Moon’s magnetic field, solar wind, and radiation environment. It provided valuable data on the space environment near the Moon.

name: Pioneer 7
details: Pioneer 7 was launched to a heliocentric orbit to study solar wind and cosmic rays. It successfully transmitted data for many years and remained in contact until 1995.

name: Luna 11
details: Luna 11 successfully entered lunar orbit and conducted studies of the Moon’s surface, radiation environment, and micrometeorite flux. It also attempted to test a TV camera system.

name: Surveyor 2
details: Surveyor 2 was a follow-up to Surveyor 1 but failed to achieve a soft landing due to a failed mid-course correction. The spacecraft crashed into the Moon.

name: Lunar Orbiter 5
details: Final mission in the Lunar Orbiter program, used to complete mapping of the Moon’s surface, including potential Apollo landing sites.

name: Surveyor 5
details: Surveyor 5 successfully landed on the Moon and conducted soil analysis using an alpha particle backscatter instrument.

name: Apollo 4
details: First test flight of the Saturn V rocket. Apollo 4 was an uncrewed mission that demonstrated the performance of the launch vehicle and heat shield.

name: Pioneer 8
details: Part of the Pioneer series for solar wind and magnetic field studies. It operated in a solar orbit outside Earth's magnetosphere.

name: Apollo 5
details: First uncrewed flight of the Apollo Lunar Module. Successfully tested ascent and descent engine systems in space.

name: Zond 4
details: Zond 4 was an uncrewed lunar flyby test mission. It failed to return safely due to a guidance error during reentry.

name: Luna 14
details: Luna 14 entered lunar orbit and conducted gravitational and radiation measurements to support crewed missions.

name: Apollo 7
details: First crewed Apollo mission. Spent 11 days in Earth orbit testing the Command Module systems and communications.

name: Pioneer 9
details: Pioneer 9 monitored solar wind and magnetic fields in solar orbit. It provided early warnings for solar storms.

name: Surveyor 7
details: Last of the Surveyor missions. Landed near the lunar highlands and provided critical data for Apollo landing site analysis.

name: Ranger 6
details: Ranger 6 successfully impacted the Moon, but failed to return any images due to a camera system malfunction. It was meant to transmit high-resolution images before impact.

name: Ranger 7
details: Ranger 7 was the first U.S. mission to transmit close-up photographs of the lunar surface back to Earth. It impacted the Moon successfully after sending over 4,000 images.

name: Mariner 3
details: Mariner 3 was a Mars flyby mission that failed due to a protective shroud not separating properly, preventing the spacecraft from achieving its planned trajectory.

name: Zond 2
details: Zond 2 was intended to fly by Mars and gather scientific data, but communication was lost before it could complete its mission. It likely flew past Mars silently in August 1965.

name: Zond 6
details: Zond 6 completed a circumlunar trajectory and returned to Earth, but depressurization caused a failure during reentry, resulting in loss of the spacecraft.

name: Venera 6
details: Venera 6 entered the Venusian atmosphere and transmitted atmospheric data for 51 minutes before being destroyed by pressure.

name: Mariner 6
details: Mariner 6 performed a successful flyby of Mars, returning images and data on the planet’s atmosphere and surface.

name: Apollo 9
details: Apollo 9 tested the Lunar Module in Earth orbit, including docking, undocking, and crew transfer procedures.

name: Mariner 7
details: Mariner 7 completed a flyby of Mars shortly after Mariner 6, providing complementary data on the atmosphere and surface.

name: Orbiting Astronomical Observatory 2
details: Nicknamed “Stargazer,” OAO‑2 carried two ultraviolet telescopes and spectrometers, observing over 1,200 targets and heralding the era of space-based astronomy.

name: Apollo 8
details: First crewed spacecraft to leave Earth orbit and circle the Moon. Carried Borman, Lovell & Anders; orbited the Moon 10 times and captured the iconic Earthrise image.

name: Luna 5
details: Luna 5 was intended to achieve a soft landing on the Moon, but due to a guidance failure, it crash-landed on the lunar surface.

name: Luna 6
details: Luna 6 missed the Moon due to a trajectory correction failure. It passed the Moon at a distance of about 160,000 km.

name: Zond 3
details: Zond 3 conducted a successful lunar flyby and returned high-quality photographs of the Moon's far side. It then continued on a trajectory into deep space for long-duration communications testing.

name: Luna 7
details: Luna 7 attempted a soft landing on the Moon but crash-landed due to a malfunction during its descent phase.

name: Soyuz 4 / Soyuz 5
details: First crewed Soviet docking mission: Soyuz 5 launched Jan 15 and docked with Soyuz 4 on Jan 16 via automated system. Crew transfer occurred manually before both safely returned.

name: Venera 5
details: A follow-up to Venera 4, Venera 5 designed to transmit atmospheric data for 53 minutes while descending under a parachute. It measured pressure, temperature, and gas composition before succumbing to extreme Venusian conditions. It also carried commemorative medallions to Venus.

name: Apollo 10
details: A full-fledged 'rehearsal' for a lunar landing, Apollo 10 brought the LM within 15 km of the lunar surface over the Sea of Tranquility before safely returning. It included photography for Apollo 11 and validated all procedures up to powered descent.

name: Apollo 11
details: The first crewed Moon landing in history. Astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface while Michael Collins remained in lunar orbit. Armstrong’s words 'That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind' became iconic.

name: Apollo 12 / Surveyor 3
details: Apollo 12 astronauts landed within walking distance of Surveyor 3 (landed April 1967), retrieved its camera and parts on Nov 19 1969. This marked the first time humans interacted with prior robotic mission hardware on the Moon.

name: Luna 15
details: Luna 15 was launched just before Apollo 11 with the goal of returning lunar soil to Earth. It crashed into the Moon during descent while Apollo 11 astronauts were still on the surface.

name: Zond 7
details: Zond 7 flew around the Moon and returned safely to Earth with high-quality photographs. It was a successful test for future crewed lunar missions.

name: Apollo 12
details: Apollo 12 was the second crewed mission to land on the Moon. The crew performed two moonwalks and visited the Surveyor 3 probe.

name: Luna 12
details: Luna 12 successfully entered lunar orbit and returned high-resolution photographs of the Moon’s surface, including images of the Sea of Rains. It helped support future landing missions.

name: Lunar Orbiter 2
details: Lunar Orbiter 2 captured detailed images of the Moon’s surface to identify potential Apollo landing sites. It famously photographed the Copernicus crater.

name: Luna 13
details: Luna 13 made a successful soft landing on the Moon and transmitted panoramic photos and data on lunar surface density, temperature, and mechanical properties.

name: Lunar Orbiter 3
details: Lunar Orbiter 3 returned high-quality photos of potential Apollo landing sites and important topographical features. It also tested spacecraft tracking systems.

name: Surveyor 3
details: Surveyor 3 landed on the Moon and conducted experiments on soil mechanics and surface conditions. Parts of it were famously retrieved by Apollo 12 astronauts in 1969.

name: Venera 2
details: Venera 2 was intended to perform a flyby of Venus and transmit scientific data, but it suffered a thermal failure and lost contact before it could return any data.

name: Luna 8
details: Luna 8 was an attempt to achieve the first soft landing on the Moon, but it crash-landed due to a parachute deployment failure during descent.

name: Pioneer 6
details: Pioneer 6 was the first of four identical spacecraft designed to study solar wind, cosmic rays, and solar magnetic fields in interplanetary space. It remained operational for decades.

name: Surveyor 1
details: Surveyor 1 was the first American spacecraft to achieve a soft landing on the Moon. It transmitted over 11,000 images and gathered valuable data on the lunar surface.

name: Apollo 13
details: Launched April 11, 1970; mission aborted after oxygen tank explosion in the service module. Crew safely returned on April 17. Famous line: “Houston, we’ve had a problem.”

name: Luna 16
details: First robotic probe to return a lunar sample to Earth. Launched Sept 12, 1970; soft–landed Sept 20 and returned soil in a sealed capsule.

name: Lunokhod 1
details: First successful remote-controlled rover on the Moon. Launched Nov 10, 1970; landed Nov 17, and traveled over 10 km gathering soil imagery and data.

name: Uhuru
details: First satellite dedicated to X‑ray astronomy. Launched Dec 12, 1970; mapped hundreds of X‑ray sources with proportional counters.

name: Venera 7
details: First successful landing on Venus’s surface and data transmission back to Earth. Launched Aug 17, 1970; landed Dec 15, 1970.

name: Salyut 1
details: First-ever space station, launched Apr 19, 1971. Hosted Soyuz crews before being decommissioned after tragic depressurization on re‑entry of Soyuz 11.

name: Orion 1
details: First of the NRO’s Orion (aka Mentor) class intelligence satellites. Launched Nov 29, 1994, used for signals intelligence gathering.

name: Apollo 15
details: Launched July 26, 1971; fourth lunar landing and first J‑class mission. Deployed Lunar Roving Vehicle and conducted extended scientific exploration.

name: Mariner 9
details: First spacecraft to orbit Mars. Arrived Nov 1971 during a dust storm; mapped 85% of the Martian surface and imaged features like Olympus Mons.

name: Mars 2
details: First spacecraft to reach Mars—but lander failed upon descent due to crash. Orbiter operated for a short time returning data.

name: Mars 3
details: First successful Mars lander—but communication failed shortly after touchdown. Orbiter broadcast data until 1972.

name: Small Astronomy Satellite 2 (SAS 2)
details: SAS 2 (Explorer 48) was NASA’s first high-resolution gamma‑ray telescope in orbit, surveying celestial gamma sources between 20 and 300 MeV. It operated until June 1973.

name: Mariner 10
details: First spacecraft to fly by two planets—Venus (Feb 1974) and Mercury (Mar 1974–Sep 1975). It imaged ~45% of Mercury’s surface and studied solar wind effects on both planets.

name: Apollo–Soyuz Test Project
details: First international human space mission: an Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft docked on July 17 1975. Crews conducted joint experiments and shared symbolic gestures, marking a milestone of détente in the space race.

name: Venera 9
details: Included an orbiter (first to orbit Venus) and a lander (first to return images from another planet’s surface). Lander touched down Oct 22 1975 and transmitted ~53 min of data and photos.

name: Viking 1 Lander
details: First successful Mars lander, touched down July 20 1976 at Chryse Planitia. Returned surface images and scientific data for over 6 years.

name: International Ultraviolet Explorer (IUE)
details: Operated for 18 years, it was the first space telescope dedicated to ultraviolet astronomy, returning over 100 000 spectra of stars, galaxies, and solar system objects.

name: Pioneer Venus Orbiter
details: Launched May 20, 1978 to study Venus’s atmosphere, clouds, and surface with 17 instruments; operated in orbit for 14 years until October 1992.

name: Voyager 1
details: Launched Sept 5, 1977, Voyager 1 performed flybys of Jupiter (1979) and Saturn (1980), then entered interstellar space in 2012. It carries the famous Golden Record and continues to transmit data.

name: STS-1 (Columbia)
details: The first orbital flight of NASA's Space Shuttle program. Carried astronauts John Young and Robert Crippen. It marked the first time a crewed spacecraft was reused and landed like an aircraft.

name: Venera 13
details: Venera 13 successfully landed on Venus and transmitted the first color images from its surface. It also analyzed soil samples and survived the harsh Venusian environment for 127 minutes.

name: ISEE-3 / International Cometary Explorer (ICE)
details: Originally placed at Earth–Sun L1 to study solar wind. Later renamed ICE and repurposed to intercept comet Giacobini–Zinner in 1985 — the first spacecraft to visit a comet.

name: Salyut 7
details: Salyut 7 was the last of the Salyut stations and served as a testbed for Mir. It hosted multiple crews and was famously repaired in orbit by Soyuz T-13 after a power failure in 1985.

name: IRAS
details: IRAS was the first-ever space telescope to perform an all-sky survey in infrared. It discovered new comets, asteroids, and over 350,000 infrared sources, reshaping our view of the cold universe.

name: Pioneer 10
details: Pioneer 10 was the first spacecraft to travel through the asteroid belt and make direct observations of Jupiter. It later became the first human-made object to leave the Solar System.

name: STS-41-B (Challenger)
details: STS-41-B was notable for the first untethered spacewalk using the Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU). It deployed two satellites and marked the fourth flight of Challenger.

name: Vega 1
details: Vega 1 deployed a Venus lander and balloon probe, then continued on to fly by Halley's Comet in March 1986. It was part of an international effort to study the comet from multiple spacecraft.

name: Voyager 2
details: Voyager 2 is the only spacecraft to visit all four giant planets: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. It conducted groundbreaking flybys and continues to send data from interstellar space.

name: Mir Core Module
details: The launch of the core module of Mir marked the beginning of the first modular space station. Mir became a symbol of long-duration space habitation and international cooperation.

name: Giotto
details: Giotto was the first European spacecraft to encounter a comet. It flew within 600 km of Halley's Comet in 1986, capturing the first close-up images of a comet nucleus.

name: Hipparcos
details: Hipparcos was the first space-based astrometry mission. It accurately measured the positions, distances, and motions of more than 100,000 stars, revolutionizing our understanding of the Milky Way.

name: COBE (Cosmic Background Explorer)
details: COBE measured the cosmic microwave background radiation and confirmed the Big Bang theory. Its data provided the first precise map of the early universe and earned a Nobel Prize in Physics.

name: Hubble Space Telescope
details: The Hubble Space Telescope has provided some of the most detailed and iconic images of the universe ever captured. Launched in 1990, it continues to revolutionize astronomy through visible, ultraviolet, and near-infrared observations.

name: Galileo
details: Galileo was the first spacecraft to orbit Jupiter. It studied the planet’s atmosphere and moons in detail, including evidence of subsurface oceans on Europa and volcanic activity on Io.

name: Ulysses
details: Ulysses was a joint ESA-NASA mission to study the Sun's poles. Using a gravity assist from Jupiter, it entered a unique orbit to observe solar wind and the heliosphere from high solar latitudes.

name: Magellan
details: Magellan was a NASA mission to map the surface of Venus using synthetic aperture radar. It produced the most detailed images of Venus to date, revealing vast volcanic plains and tectonic features.

name: ETS-VI (Kiku-6)
details: ETS-VI was designed to demonstrate advanced satellite communication technologies and geostationary positioning. The mission failed due to a malfunction in the launch vehicle's second stage.

name: HALCA (VSOP)
details: HALCA was the first space-based radio telescope dedicated to Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI). It extended baseline distances by working in conjunction with ground-based observatories.

name: Mars Pathfinder / Sojourner
details: Mars Pathfinder delivered the Sojourner rover to the surface of Mars, marking the first successful rover mission. It tested key technologies and collected valuable data on the Martian atmosphere, geology, and surface conditions.

name: Mars Global Surveyor
details: Mars Global Surveyor mapped the entire Martian surface and provided high-resolution imagery and topographic data. It operated successfully for nearly a decade and contributed significantly to our understanding of the Red Planet.

name: International Space Station (Zarya Module)
details: The Zarya module was the first component of the International Space Station. Launched by Russia with U.S. funding, it provided initial power and propulsion. It marked the beginning of continuous human presence in space aboard the ISS.

name: NEAR Shoemaker
details: NEAR Shoemaker became the first spacecraft to orbit and then land on an asteroid (433 Eros). It studied the asteroid's composition, morphology, and magnetic field, providing invaluable data on small Solar System bodies.

name: Expedition 1
details: Expedition 1 was the first long-duration crew aboard the ISS. The crew spent over four months on the station, initiating continuous human presence in orbit that continues to this day.

name: SPOT 4
details: SPOT 4 continued France's Earth observation program, providing high-resolution imagery for agriculture, forestry, and environmental monitoring. It included a new sensor for vegetation tracking.

name: CSXT GoFast
details: The GoFast rocket, built by the Civilian Space eXploration Team, became the first amateur rocket to reach space, reaching an altitude of 116 km. It demonstrated the feasibility of civilian spaceflight.

name: Cassini–Huygens
details: Cassini–Huygens was a landmark mission to Saturn. Cassini orbited Saturn and studied its rings and moons for 13 years, while the ESA-built Huygens probe landed on Titan, the first landing in the outer Solar System.

name: Genesis
details: Genesis collected solar wind particles to study the composition of the Sun. Though the return capsule crash-landed due to parachute failure, some samples were salvaged and provided valuable solar data.

name: Deep Impact
details: Deep Impact was a NASA mission that launched an impactor into comet Tempel 1 to study its composition. The collision created a crater and ejected material, allowing scientists to study the comet’s interior.

name: Hayabusa
details: Hayabusa was the first mission to return samples from an asteroid. It landed on asteroid Itokawa, collected dust particles, and returned them to Earth in 2010, despite multiple technical issues.

name: Stardust
details: Stardust collected samples from the coma of comet Wild 2 and returned them to Earth in 2006. It was the first mission to bring back cometary dust and interstellar particles.

name: Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter
details: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter is equipped with a powerful camera and instruments to study Mars’ surface, climate, and subsurface. It has provided some of the highest resolution images of Mars ever captured.

name: Chandrayaan-1
details: India’s first mission to the Moon, Chandrayaan-1 orbited the Moon and released the Moon Impact Probe. It discovered water molecules on the lunar surface and helped establish ISRO’s capabilities in deep space exploration.

name: Kepler Mission
details: The Kepler space telescope monitored over 150,000 stars to detect Earth-sized planets in the habitable zone. It revolutionized our understanding of planetary systems by confirming thousands of exoplanets.

name: IKAROS
details: IKAROS was the first spacecraft to successfully demonstrate solar sail propulsion in interplanetary space. It deployed a 20-meter sail and used sunlight to generate thrust, pioneering low-cost, fuel-free space travel.

name: ARTEMIS-P1
details: Originally part of the THEMIS constellation, ARTEMIS-P1 was repurposed to study the Moon’s magnetosphere. It became the first spacecraft to enter a stable lunar orbit from a Lagrange point.

name: ARTEMIS-P2
details: ARTEMIS-P2 followed its twin (P1) into lunar orbit to form a dual-satellite mission studying the Moon’s magnetic and plasma environment. Together, they provided critical data on solar wind interaction with the lunar surface.

name: MESSENGER
details: MESSENGER was the first spacecraft to orbit Mercury. It conducted detailed mapping and analysis of the planet’s composition, magnetic field, and exosphere, significantly advancing our understanding of Mercury.

name: Dawn
details: Dawn was the first mission to orbit two extraterrestrial bodies, Vesta and Ceres, in the asteroid belt. It used ion propulsion to travel between them, providing unprecedented insights into early solar system formation.

name: Mars Science Laboratory (Curiosity)
details: Curiosity is a car-sized rover that landed in Gale Crater to explore Mars’ climate and geology, and assess whether it ever had environmental conditions favorable for microbial life. It remains active today.

name: Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter
details: LRO mapped the Moon in high resolution, identifying potential landing sites for future missions and studying the lunar environment. It remains operational, continuing to return valuable scientific data.

name: Rosetta
details: Rosetta was the first spacecraft to orbit a comet. It traveled for over 10 years before arriving at Comet 67P, where it deployed the Philae lander and conducted close-up studies of the comet's nucleus and activity.

name: Philae
details: Philae was the first spacecraft to land on a comet. It transmitted data from the surface of 67P, including analyses of its composition. Despite a rough landing, it provided groundbreaking scientific results.

name: New Horizons
details: New Horizons performed the first flyby of Pluto in 2015, returning detailed images and data of the dwarf planet. It later explored a Kuiper Belt object, 486958 Arrokoth, continuing to expand our knowledge of the solar system's outer reaches.

name: New Shepard 2
details: This was the first successful vertical landing of Blue Origin’s New Shepard booster after a suborbital flight, marking a major milestone in reusable rocket technology.

name: Falcon 9 First Successful Landing
destination: Low Earth Orbit (Orbital deployment + booster recovery)
details: This mission marked the first successful vertical landing of the Falcon 9 booster on solid ground, demonstrating SpaceX’s reusability breakthrough.

name: BEAM
details: BEAM was an experimental expandable habitat module sent to the ISS to test the feasibility of inflatable structures for future space missions.

name: Hayabusa2
details: Hayabusa2 successfully traveled to asteroid Ryugu, collected samples, and returned them to Earth in 2020. It was a landmark in robotic sample-return technology.

name: InSight
details: InSight is a robotic lander designed to study the interior structure and seismic activity of Mars. It deployed the first seismometer directly on the Martian surface.

name: Chang'e 4
details: Chang'e 4 was the first mission to successfully soft-land on the far side of the Moon. It deployed the Yutu-2 rover and conducts geological and biological experiments.

name: Ingenuity
details: Ingenuity made history as the first powered flight on another planet. Initially a tech demo, it completed dozens of flights, greatly exceeding its expected mission duration.

name: MOXIE
details: The Mars Oxygen In-Situ Resource Utilization Experiment (MOXIE) successfully demonstrated the production of oxygen from the Martian atmosphere, a crucial step for future human missions.

name: Parker Solar Probe
details: The Parker Solar Probe is the closest spacecraft ever sent to the Sun. It studies the solar corona and solar wind to better understand space weather and the Sun's behavior.

name: James Webb Space Telescope
details: The most powerful space telescope ever built, JWST observes in infrared to study the early universe, star and planet formation, and distant exoplanets.

name: DART (Double Asteroid Redirection Test)
details: DART was the first mission to intentionally alter the motion of a celestial body. It impacted asteroid moonlet Dimorphos to test kinetic impact as a method of asteroid deflection.

name: Chandrayaan-3
details: Chandrayaan-3 successfully delivered the Vikram lander and Pragyan rover to the Moon, making India the first country to land near the lunar south pole.

name: Starship Flight Test 3
details: The third integrated flight test of Starship reached near-orbital speeds but ended prematurely during reentry. It demonstrated key progress in orbital flight objectives.

name: Starship Flight Test 4
details: The fourth Starship flight test achieved a near-complete flight profile with successful stage separation, orbital insertion, and controlled reentry of both booster and ship.

name: Chang’e 6
details: Chang’e 6 is the first mission to return samples from the far side of the Moon. It collected and returned lunar regolith, providing unique insight into lunar geology.

name: Starship Flight Test 5
details: Fifth integrated Starship flight — first to demonstrate tower catch of the Super Heavy booster (‘Mechazilla’) and splashdown of the upper stage in the Indian Ocean.

name: Blue Ghost Mission 1
details: First privately developed lunar lander to touch down on the Moon. Landed March 2 2025, conducted 14 days of surface operations, and captured high‑def images including a lunar sunset.

name: Fram2
details: First private crewed polar orbital mission. Launched with four civilians on April 1, 2025, it conducted scientific observations over Earth's poles and landed in the Pacific on April 4.

name: ESCAPADE
details: Twin spacecraft (Blue & Gold) to study Mars’s magnetosphere and response to solar wind. Launch readiness planned for late 2025 aboard New Glenn.

name: Europa Clipper
details: Will conduct multiple flybys of Europa to assess its habitability, using a powerful suite of instruments to study its ice shell, ocean, and atmosphere.

name: Dragonfly
details: A dual-quadcopter lander to explore Titan’s surface and chemistry; first powered aircraft to operate off Earth. Launch is planned for July 2028.

name: JUICE
details: ESA mission to study Jupiter’s icy moons (Ganymede, Callisto, Europa). Launched April 14 2023; Ganymede orbital insertion slated for July 2031.

name: Lucy
details: On a 12-year mission to fly by eight asteroids (main-belt & Jupiter Trojans). Launched October 16 2021, already encountered Dinkinesh (2023) and Donaldjohanson (2025), heading to Trojan swarm in 2027+.

name: VERITAS
details: Will map Venus’s surface with high-resolution radar and spectroscopy to understand its tectonic history, volcanic processes, and atmospheric composition. Launch targeted mid-2031.
